content.webTitle: Pick of the day: Twenty Minutes: The Great British Summer Time | Costing the Earth

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.bodyText: When he wasn't inventing lightning conductors, catheters and American constitutions, Benjamin Franklin seems to have passed the time lecturing people about the evils of the lie-in. "Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise," was his best-known saying. His kids must have hated him. Anyway. In 1784, while Franklin was living in Paris, he wrote an allegedly humorous letter to the French encouraging them to cut their candle bills by getting up with the sun. "Oblige a man to rise at four in the morning," he wrote, "and it is probable he will go willingly to bed at eight in the evening." And that, dear readers, was the first step on the road to daylight saving. You can hear about the rest of them in Twenty Minutes: The Great British Summer Time (8.05pm, Radio 3). Or you could join Costing the Earth (9pm, Radio 4) in a field full of organic tents, wind-powered toilets and biodegradable sound systems. Tom Robinson is investigating festivals' attempts to reduce their environmental impact.
